question.content:
The area of the hexagon in the $PV$ diagram below is $6\times 10^3\ \text J$. The area of the shaded rectangle is $4\times10^3\ \text J$.

[[☃ image 1]]

**Find the work done by the system in going from state $\text B$ to state $\text A$ along the hexagon.**

[[☃ numeric-input 1]] $\times 10^3\ \text J$

hints.content:
##Strategy

The work done by a gas in a process can be found by calculating the area under the $P-V$ curve. For a cyclic process, the area *inside* the closed curve is the net work done.

So,

$\begin{align} 
&\text{Total Area}=W_{\text {net}} \\\\
 &=\blueE{W_{\text B \rightarrow \text A \text{ along hexagon}}}+\redD{W_{\text A \rightarrow \text B\text{ along straight line}}}
 \end{align}$

*Note: For a clockwise cycle, the net work done is positive, and for an anticlockwise cycle, the net work done is negative.*

[[☃ explanation 3]]

options.explanation:
For a clockwise cycle, the area for the expansion part of the cycle is more than the area for the contraction part. The reverse is true for an anti-clockwise cycle.

For instance in the figure below,

[[☃ image 2]]

- The gas is contracting from $\text B$ to $\text A$. The area under this part is shaded red.

- The gas is expanding from $\text A$ to $\text B$. This area under this part is shaded blue.

There is more red area, so the net work done is negative.

hints.content:
##Solution

Following from above,

$\begin{align}
W_{\text{net}} &=\blueE{W_{\text B \rightarrow \text A \text{ along hexagon}}}+\redD{W_{\text A \rightarrow \text B\text{ along straight line}}}\\\\
\Rightarrow 6\times10^3\ \text J &=\blueE{W_{\text B \rightarrow \text A \text{ along hexagon}}}\redD{+4\times 10^3\ \text J} \\\\
 \Rightarrow  \blueE{W_{\text B \rightarrow \text A}}  &= 2\times 10^3\ \text J
\end{align}$

The net work done is positive as the cycle is clockwise.  $\redD{W_{\text A \rightarrow \text B}}$ is positive as the gas is expanding.

The work done in going from $\text B$ to $\text A$ along the hexagon is:

$\boxed{2}\times10^3\ \text J$
